topic_seeds.description: Dealing with family dynamics and expectations
Persistent worry about various life aspects

flaw_patterns.name: contradicting_self
flaw_patterns.description: Says opposite things across different exchanges

flaw_patterns.name: yes_but
flaw_patterns.description: Rejects suggestions while appearing to engage

flaw_patterns.name: seeking_reassurance
flaw_patterns.description: Wants to be told it's fine rather than exploring

exchanges.user:
So I'm not even sure where to start with this. Work has been absolute garbage the last few weeks, and I keep telling myself it's fine, it's temporary, everyone has rough patches. But honestly? I'm starting to wonder if that's just me making excuses.

My manager asked me to lead this new project and I said yes because apparently I can't say no to anything, even when I'm already drowning in meetings and deadlines. Part of me thought maybe it would be good, you know, prove I can handle more responsibility. But the second I committed I regretted it. Now I'm stuck and everyone's counting on me and I'm pretty sure I'm gonna mess it up.

What's weird is my mom called yesterday and actually asked how I was doing. Like genuinely asked. And instead of being honest I just told her everything was fine, which is stupid because she would probably just tell me I take on too much anyway, and then we'd fight about it like we always do. So what's the point.

Anyway, the work thing is what's eating at me the most right now. I don't even know what I'm looking for here, just needed to get it out I guess.
exchanges.assistant:
ello. You've packed a lot in here—work pressure, the new project, your mom, the pattern of saying yes when you want to say no. Let me respond to each.

**The new project and saying yes:**
You said yes even though you knew the second you committed you regretted it. That's a hard thing to notice—most people don't have that immediate clarity. And then you can't say no because you can't say no to anything. That pattern is doing something to you: you're stuck, everyone's counting on you, and you're convinced you're going to mess it up. What if the evidence was different? What if you've actually handled hard things before and this is just another version of that?

**Work being "absolute garbage":**
You keep telling yourself it's fine and temporary, but you're starting to wonder if it's you making excuses. I'm curious—what would it mean if it really was just a tough patch and not about you? Sometimes we're so used to blaming ourselves that we can't see the other factors. Is the work environment actually bad, or is the pressure on you to perform multiple roles at once making it feel worse?

**Your mom:**
She asked how you were doing, and you told her everything was fine instead of being honest. You said that's stupid because she'd tell you you take on too much and then you'd fight. I get why you'd want to avoid that. But what if there's another way—like being honest but also naming what you need? Not "you're right, I take on too much" but "I'm overwhelmed right now, and I don't know how to change it yet." Sometimes that's less of a fight than just giving the yes/no answer.

**What you're looking for:**
You said you don't know what you're looking for. That's okay. Sometimes all you need is to get the weight off your chest and see what's there. What feels most urgent to you right now—the project itself, the pattern of saying yes, the relationship with your mom, or something else?

exchanges.user:
So i talked to my manager about scaling back on the project stuff. Thought maybe that would help, you know? He basically said yeah we can redistribute some tasks but the core leadership piece is still on me because "no one else has the bandwidth right now." Which is fair i guess but also like... that's not actually solving anything is it.

Been thinking about what you said about my mom though. That thing about being honest but also saying what i need. I tried it actually. She called again and instead of just saying everything's fine i told her work was stressing me out. And she was like "yeah you always do this to yourself" which... okay cool, exactly what i was worried about. So that didn't really work out.

Anyway work is still a mess. Got through the week though. The project kickoff is next week and i'm honestly dreading it but whatever, gonna happen regardless. Part of me thinks if i just push through hard enough for like three months then it'll get better and i can breathe again. That's probably not realistic but it's the plan rn.
exchanges.assistant:
**The scaling back conversation:**
You talked to your manager and thought maybe that would help, but he said the core leadership piece is still on you. That's not actually solving anything, you're right. You're still carrying the weight, just with slightly less on the edges. And here's the thing—you tried to advocate for yourself, and the answer was "no one else has bandwidth." That's not a problem with you or your capabilities. That's a problem with the team's capacity. What would it look like to push back again, not asking to be off the project but asking what "no one else has bandwidth" actually means in practice? Is that true, or is it just easier to leave you doing everything?

**The mom conversation:**
You tried being honest and naming what you need, and she said "yeah you always do this to yourself." That landed hard. I can hear you—it's exactly what you were worried about. But I want to slow down on that moment. "You always do this to yourself"—is that her blaming you, or is there something else in that? Sometimes people say hurt things when they're frustrated or scared. Did she say anything else, or was that the whole thing? And when she said that, what did you feel in your body?

**Work still a mess, but you got through the week:**
The project kickoff is next week and you're dreading it. You're going to push through for three months, hoping it gets better. That's the plan. That's not realistic, and you know it's not realistic. Three months of pushing through hard—that's not breathing again, that's just delaying the collapse. I'm not saying you have to quit the project or blow up at your manager right now. But I want to name what's happening: you're setting yourself up to burn out because the current plan is "endure it until it's over." What if the goal wasn't just to survive the next three months, but to actually change what's making it unbearable?

exchanges.user:
quick update on the mom thing - she texted me this morning asking if i wanted to grab coffee this weekend. which is... i don't know. nice? confusing? like maybe she wasn't mad at me, she was just being her usual self. or maybe she felt bad. anyway i said yeah.

the project kickoff is tomorrow and i'm not sleeping great about it. been having that thing where you're tired but your brain won't shut up, you know? keep running through scenarios of what could go wrong. which is stupid because i can't control half of it anyway.

but here's the thing - i realized something. when you said "what if the current plan is just endure it until it's over" it hit different than i expected. because that IS exactly what i'm doing. and i've been doing that my whole life tbh. just push through, white knuckle it, wait for the next thing. my ex used to say i was like... unreachable when i get in that mode. which is fair. 

idk. i don't have an answer to what would actually change it. feels like the project is just the thing that's on my plate right now, and i can't exactly not do it. so what else is there? just accept it's gonna suck for three months?
exchanges.assistant:
**The coffee text from your mom:**
She texted asking if you want to grab coffee this weekend. That's interesting—she didn't just say "you always do this to yourself" and end it. She came back. That could mean she wasn't mad at you, or maybe she felt bad, or maybe she's just being her usual self. You don't know yet, and that's okay. What matters is that there's an offer on the table. When you go to that coffee, you can try the thing you tried before—being honest and naming what you need—but you can also just listen and see what she actually wants. Sometimes people surprise you when you give them room to say more than just their frustration.

**Project kickoff tomorrow and the sleep thing:**
You're not sleeping great, and your brain won't shut up. You keep running through scenarios of what could go wrong, and you know it's stupid because you can't control half of it. That's the anxiety doing its thing—trying to prepare for every disaster by running through every possibility. But here's the pattern I'm noticing: you can't control what goes wrong, and you're spending energy on trying to. That's exhausting. What if the goal for tomorrow wasn't to have it perfect, but just to get through it without collapsing? You don't have to have the plan figured out. You just have to show up and do the thing.

**The realization about the pattern:**
You said something important: you realized the current plan is to endure it until it's over. And that's exactly what you've been doing your whole life—push through, white-knuckle it, wait for the next thing. Your ex said you're unreachable when you get in that mode, and that's fair. You're right that you've been doing this for a long time. And you're asking the right question: what would actually change it?

Here's what I'm hearing: you can't just stop the project. It's on your plate, you can't exactly not do it. So the question isn't "how do I quit the project" or "how do I stop taking on too much." The question is: what's one small thing you could do differently *within* this project that doesn't require you to white-knuckle it until it's over? Maybe it's asking for help earlier than you usually would. Maybe it's naming one thing you can't control and deciding not to spend energy on it. Maybe it's just noticing the moments you're pushing through and naming it to someone—your manager, a coworker, even just to yourself.

You don't have to have the whole answer. You just have to start noticing that enduring until it's over isn't working, and you're open to trying something different. That's the shift.

exchanges.user:
so the kickoff happened yesterday and it was... fine? not great, not a disaster. i showed up, laid out the timeline, people asked questions i could mostly answer. there were a few moments where i felt like i had no idea what i was doing but i just kept talking and nobody seemed to notice so whatever.

the thing is though - and this is gonna sound contradictory - but i felt better during it than i expected to. like i was dreading it so much in my head that the actual thing wasn't as bad. which makes me think maybe i've been catastrophizing more than the situation actually warrants. but also that doesn't mean the project isn't still a ton of work, right? just because one meeting went okay doesn't mean the next three months are gonna be fine.

also grabbed coffee with my mom this morning. it was... actually decent? she asked about work and i told her about the project and instead of the "you always do this" thing she just listened mostly. asked me how i was feeling about it. which was weird in a good way i think. we didn't solve anything or whatever but it felt less like we were fighting and more like we were just talking. idk if that sticks or if we'll be back to the usual dynamic next time but at least it was different.

anyway. still tired. brain's still loud. but maybe slightly less catastrophizing? idk.
exchanges.assistant:
**The kickoff:**
It was fine. Not great, not a disaster. You showed up, laid out the timeline, answered questions. There were moments where you felt like you had no idea what you were doing, but you kept talking and nobody noticed. That's the thing about anxiety—it builds up this whole catastrophe in your head, and then the actual thing is just... a meeting. You were dreading it so much that the real thing felt better than expected. That's not contradictory, that's actually really useful information. You've been catastrophizing more than the situation warrants. The project is still a ton of work, sure. But the kickoff wasn't the disaster you were bracing for. That's worth noticing.

**The pattern of catastrophizing:**
You're right that one meeting going okay doesn't mean the next three months are gonna be fine. But it does mean that your brain's threat detection system is running hot. It's scanning for disaster in every direction, spending energy on things you can't control. That's exhausting. And it's not accurate. What if you started catching that pattern earlier—like in the middle of the catastrophizing thought and naming it to yourself? "Oh, there's the disaster voice again." Not to shut it down, just to notice it's there and not let it take over the whole story.

**Coffee with your mom:**
That was actually decent. She asked about the project and listened mostly. Asked how you were feeling about it. No "you always do this to yourself" this time. It felt less like fighting and more like just talking. You said it might be a fluke, or maybe the dynamic will go back to usual next time. But I don't think it was a fluke. You tried being honest and vulnerable, and she met you there. That's what happened. You don't have to force it to be the new normal. It can just be what happened this time. And if it happens again, you'll know it's not a one-off.

exchanges.user:
ok so i've been thinking about what you said about catching the catastrophizing earlier. tried it a couple times this week and honestly it's kinda working? like i'll notice the disaster voice and just be like "yeah that's not real" and move on. it's weird how much mental energy that frees up.

but then today happened and i'm not sure if i'm doing the thing or if this is actually legitimate concern. had a meeting with one of the stakeholders and they pointed out some gaps in the project plan. nothing catastrophic, just stuff we didn't think through. and my brain immediately went to "see, you're gonna screw this up, everyone's gonna know you're incompetent." but i also realized... maybe i just need to actually fix those gaps? like that's the actual problem, not that i'm incompetent.

which sounds obvious when i say it out loud but it feels different from how i usually think about stuff.

the other thing is work's been slightly less suffocating this week. still busy, still stressful, but i don't know. different energy maybe. or maybe i'm just getting used to it. idk.

my mom's been texting me more. like actually checking in, not just surface stuff. which is nice but also i'm waiting for the other shoe to drop tbh. like when's she gonna circle back to criticizing me or whatever. that's the pattern, right? so part of me doesn't want to get too comfortable thinking things are actually different with her.
exchanges.assistant:
**Catching the catastrophizing:**
You tried naming the disaster voice a couple times this week and it's actually working. You notice it, say "yeah that's not real," and move on. That's the skill working. And then today, the stakeholder pointed out gaps in the project plan, and your brain went straight to "you're gonna screw this up, everyone's gonna know you're incompetent." But you caught it this time. You realized—maybe I just need to fix those gaps? That's the actual problem, not that you're incompetent. You said it sounds obvious when you say it out loud, but it feels different from how you usually think about stuff. It is different. That's the shift. You're starting to hear the thought, separate it from the fact, and respond to the real problem instead of spending energy on the catastrophe. That's not a small thing. That's you rewiring how your brain responds to criticism.

**Work being slightly less suffocating:**
Work's been slightly less suffocating this week. Still busy, still stressful, but different energy. You're not sure if it's actually different or if you're just getting used to it. I think you're probably getting used to it, but there's something else happening too. You're not white-knuckling as hard. You're not catastrophizing as much. You're catching the disaster voice and responding instead of letting it take over. That's probably part of why it feels different. The work itself hasn't changed, but you're engaging with it differently.

**Your mom texting more and waiting for the other shoe to drop:**
Your mom's been checking in, actually asking about you. It's nice, but you're waiting for the other shoe to drop. When's she gonna circle back to criticizing you or whatever. That's the pattern, right? So you're not going to get too comfortable thinking things are actually different. I get why you're doing that. You've been in this dynamic for a long time. One good conversation doesn't erase the pattern. But here's the thing: she's been texting more. She came back to coffee. She listened instead of criticized. That's not nothing. The other shoe dropping might be real, but it doesn't have to mean the good stuff never happened. You can notice both things: "she's being nicer this week" and "I'm waiting for her to criticize me again." You don't have to pick one.

exchanges.user:
ugh ok so this is gonna sound stupid but my mom called me yesterday and we actually had like a real conversation? not just her asking surface questions and me deflecting. she was asking about the project gaps thing and i told her what happened and instead of the usual "i told you so" vibe she just... listened? and then she was like "sounds like you're handling it better than you think you are." which like, maybe she's right but also i don't trust it yet because that's not really her style.

anyway that's not even the main thing. work got messier this week. not in like a catastrophic way but the timeline we presented is already slipping because one of the teams didn't scope things right on their end. and my brain immediately went to that place where i'm like "this is your fault, you should have caught that, everyone's gonna blame you." except this time i actually caught myself doing it. i was like okay that's the disaster voice, this isn't actually about me being incompetent, this is about a team that didn't communicate what they needed.

but here's where i'm contradicting myself or whatever - because even though i know it's not my fault, i still feel like it IS my fault? like logically i get that the gap in communication wasn't on me, but i'm still sitting here feeling like i screwed up. so catching the thought is working but it's not making the feeling go away. which makes me wonder if the whole thing is actually just... a distraction from the real problem that i genuinely am bad at this and i'm just not seeing it yet.
exchanges.assistant:
**Your mom's call:**
She actually had a real conversation with you. Not surface questions, not deflecting. You told her about the project gaps and instead of "I told you so," she just listened. And then she said "sounds like you're handling it better than you think you are." That's not her usual style, and you don't trust it yet. That makes sense. One good conversation doesn't erase the pattern. But it's also not nothing. She's showing up differently. You don't have to trust it fully yet. You can just notice that it happened and see what it means.

**Catching the disaster voice:**
The timeline is slipping because one of the teams didn't scope things right on their end. Your brain went to "this is your fault, you should have caught that, everyone's gonna blame you." And this time, you caught it. You separated the thought from the fact. You said "that's the disaster voice, this is about a team that didn't communicate what they needed." That's the skill working. You're not letting the catastrophic thought take over the whole story. You're hearing it, naming it, and responding to the real problem.

**The contradiction: you know it's not your fault, but you still feel like it is:**
This is where the real work happens. You said catching the thought is working but it's not making the feeling go away. So you're still sitting here feeling like you screwed up, even though you know logically the gap in communication wasn't on you. That's not a contradiction. That's actually exactly what's supposed to happen. The catastrophic thought is the loud voice that you're catching. The feeling is what's left. And that feeling—that's the part that's real. Not because you're bad at this, but because you care about the project and you're worried about what it means for you and the team.

But here's the thing: the feeling doesn't have to mean you're bad at this. You can feel bad about it and still be handling it better than you think you are. Those aren't mutually exclusive. You're not perfect at this. The team didn't communicate. That's real. And you're also not the person who caused that. That's also real. Both things are true. And the fact that you feel bad about it doesn't mean you're actually bad at it—it just means you're human and you care.

**The distraction theory: maybe the real problem is that you're genuinely bad at this:**
You're wondering if the whole thing is just a distraction from the real problem—that you're genuinely bad at this and you're not seeing it yet. But I'm curious. What evidence do you actually have that you're bad at this? You led a project kickoff. You caught the catastrophic thought. You're working with stakeholders. The timeline slipped because of a communication gap, and you're not blaming yourself for that. That's not what "bad at this" looks like. That's what someone who's learning to handle this well looks like.

exchanges.user:
been a few days and honestly things feel a bit different. the project's still moving, we're addressing those gaps from the stakeholder meeting. it's not perfect but it's working. i'm still catching myself in that catastrophic spiral sometimes but less often, which is something i guess.

but here's what's been weird - my mom and i have been texting more regularly now. like actually regular check-ins, not just her reaching out when she's worried. and i know you said not to wait for the other shoe to drop but it's hard not to. we're supposed to grab lunch this weekend and part of me is genuinely looking forward to it, which feels foreign honestly. like i'm waiting for it to blow up but also maybe it won't? i don't know how to sit with that.

the other thing that's been bugging me though is like... i realized i'm catching the disaster voice more easily now, which is good, but sometimes i wonder if i'm just getting better at ignoring my actual instincts. like what if those feelings are telling me something real? what if when my brain says "you're gonna mess this up" it's actually picking up on something i'm not seeing? i know that probably sounds paranoid but i can't shake it.

work's still work. tired still. but the suffocating feeling has eased up a bit which is weird because nothing actually changed about the workload. so maybe it really was just how i was thinking about it.
exchanges.assistant:
**Things feel different:**
The project's moving, the gaps from the stakeholder meeting are being addressed. It's not perfect but it's working. You're still catching the catastrophic spiral sometimes but less often. That's something. That's the pattern starting to shift. And here's the thing: you're noticing that even though the project isn't perfect, it's working. That's different from waiting for the disaster voice to confirm you're screwing everything up. You're letting reality be what it is instead of what your anxiety tells you it is.

**Your mom and the lunch:**
She's texting more regularly now—actual regular check-ins, not just when she's worried. And you're supposed to grab lunch this weekend. Part of you is genuinely looking forward to it, which feels foreign. You're waiting for it to blow up but also maybe it won't. You said it's hard to sit with that. That makes sense. You've been in this relationship for a long time, and one good conversation doesn't erase the pattern. But here's what I'm hearing: you're looking forward to it. That's real. And the fact that you can't shake the feeling it might blow up doesn't mean it will. It just means you're not ready to trust that things are different yet. You can notice both: "I'm looking forward to this" and "I'm also waiting for it to go wrong." Both can be true. You don't have to pick one.

**What if the feelings are telling you something real, not just anxiety?**
You're catching the disaster voice more easily, and that's good. But sometimes you wonder if you're just getting better at ignoring your actual instincts. What if when your brain says "you're gonna mess this up," it's actually picking up on something you're not seeing? That thought doesn't sound paranoid. That sounds like curiosity. You're asking: is this anxiety, or is this a real warning? And here's the thing: sometimes the feeling *is* telling you something real. The difference is that the feeling and the catastrophic thought don't always match up. The catastrophic thought is "you're gonna mess this up." The feeling is the anxiety. The real warning might be "this is risky and I need to pay attention." But that's not the same as "you're incompetent and everyone's gonna know."

What if you tested that theory? Next time the disaster voice says "you're gonna mess this up," you could ask: "what am I actually feeling, and what would I need to do if this was true?" Maybe the answer is "I'm scared and I need to double-check this." Maybe it's "this is hard and I need to talk to my manager about the timeline." Maybe it's "I don't know and I need to ask for help." That's you listening to the instinct instead of just dismissing it. But you're also not letting it take over the whole story. You're hearing it, understanding it, and then deciding what to do.

**The suffocating feeling eased up even though nothing changed about the workload:**
Work's still work. You're still tired. But the suffocating feeling has eased up a bit, and you said that's weird because nothing actually changed about the workload. You're right. Nothing changed. The project is still demanding. You're still leading it. The difference is that you're not catastrophizing as much. You're not spending energy on the disaster voice. You're just showing up and doing the work. And that shift in how you're thinking about it is what's making the feeling less suffocating. That's not nothing. That's you changing the story you're telling yourself, and that story is what's making it hard to breathe.

exchanges.user:
So the lunch with my mom happened and honestly it went really well? Like we actually talked about real stuff. She asked about the project and i told her the truth about how stressed i've been, and she didn't make it about me being stupid or whatever. She actually gave me some advice about delegating more, which normally would annoy me but this time it landed different. She seemed like she actually cared.

But here's the thing that's messing with me - and i know this probably sounds crazy - but after it went so well i kind of spiraled a bit? Like i got home and started thinking about all the ways it could fall apart again. Like she's being nice now but what if next week she says something cutting and ruins it? Or what if i do something that disappoints her? I know logically that's the disaster voice doing its thing but it feels different this time. It feels like i'm protecting myself from getting hurt again.

Work's been fine actually. Like genuinely fine. The team addressed the scope issue, we're back on track with the timeline. I'm still tired but it doesn't feel crushing anymore. Got through the week without that white-knuckling feeling. So that part is actually better.

But i guess i'm wondering - is it weird that the mom thing feels harder than the work thing right now? Like i can catch the catastrophic thoughts about the project and move on, but with her it's like... i don't want to move on from the worry? Like the worry is what's keeping me safe? That probably doesn't make sense.
exchanges.assistant:
**The lunch with your mom:**
It went really well. You actually talked about real stuff. You told her the truth about how stressed you've been, and she didn't make it about you being stupid. She gave advice about delegating more, and this time it landed different. She seemed like she actually cared. That's not a small thing. That's her showing up differently, and you noticed it. You're not just hearing it—you're feeling it.

**The spiral after:**
You got home and started thinking about all the ways it could fall apart again. What if next week she says something cutting? What if you do something that disappoints her? You know it's the disaster voice, and you're right that it's doing its thing. But you said it feels different this time. It feels like you're protecting yourself from getting hurt again. That makes sense. You've been in this relationship for a long time, and one good conversation doesn't erase the pattern. The worry is your brain's way of saying "don't trust this yet, you don't know what's coming." And part of you is holding onto that worry as a way of bracing for impact.

But here's what I'm hearing: the worry is keeping you safe from disappointment, not from something real. She said something nice this week. She listened, she cared, she gave you advice that landed differently. That's what happened. And the worry is trying to protect you from it happening again. You don't have to move on from the worry, but you can also notice that it's not actually protecting you—it's just keeping you at arm's length from a relationship that might actually be getting better.

**Work is genuinely better:**
The team addressed the scope issue, you're back on track with the timeline. You're still tired but it doesn't feel crushing anymore. You got through the week without the white-knuckling feeling. That's real progress. You're not catastrophizing as much. You're catching the disaster voice and responding to the real problem. And the work is actually getting better because of that.

**Is it weird that the mom thing feels harder right now?**
You're asking if it's weird that the mom thing feels harder than the work thing right now. You can catch the catastrophic thoughts about the project and move on, but with her it's like the worry is what's keeping you safe. You said that probably doesn't make sense. It does make sense. The work thing is external. You can fix the project, address the gaps, and the catastrophic thought has a clear answer: "fix this, that's the problem." The mom thing is internal. The worry isn't about a specific thing you can fix—it's about trusting that this is actually different. And trust is hard. You've been burned before. One good lunch doesn't erase the pattern. So your brain is holding onto the worry as a way of protecting you from being disappointed again.

But here's the thing: the worry is keeping you safe from what? The relationship is actually getting better. You can feel that. She's showing up differently. She cares about you. And the worry is trying to keep you at a distance from that. That's not protection. That's you choosing not to let yourself feel good about something that's actually happening. You don't have to force yourself to stop worrying. But you can start noticing it and asking: "what am I protecting myself from?" And then see if there's a different way to respond to that.

exchanges.user:
Yeah so i've been sitting with that stuff you said about the worry keeping me safe. Didn't really help tbh. Like intellectually i get it but it's not changing how i feel, so what's the point of understanding it if nothing shifts?

Anyway my mom texted asking if i want to come over for dinner next weekend. Which is fine, i'll probably go. But i also realized something - when she's nice to me i get anxious, and when she's critical i get anxious. So like... either way i'm anxious about it. Which makes me think maybe the problem isn't actually about her being nice or mean, it's just that i'm always waiting for something bad to happen with her no matter what she does.

Work stuff is still good though. Project's humming along, no major fires. Honestly feels almost boring now which is weird because a month ago i was convinced the whole thing was gonna explode. So i guess that's proof that my brain was just catastrophizing? But also now i'm second-guessing whether i'm actually leading well or if everyone's just being polite and not telling me i'm messing up.

Haven't been sleeping great again actually. Not the anxious brain thing like before - just physically restless. Can't get comfortable, wake up at like 3am and can't fall back asleep. Idk if that's stress or just getting older or what.
exchanges.assistant:
**The worry keeping you safe:**
You said understanding it didn't really help, because it's not changing how you feel. So what's the point of intellectualizing it if nothing shifts? That's fair. I can't make the worry go away by explaining it. But here's the thing: you're right that understanding it doesn't fix it. And I'm not trying to do that. I'm trying to help you notice that the worry isn't actually protecting you—it's just running in the background, keeping you at arm's length from a relationship that might be getting better. The feeling is what matters. The understanding is just context. You don't need to do anything with it. You can just know that the worry is there, and the relationship is still there, and both things are real.

**With your mom, either way you're anxious:**
She texted asking if you want to come over for dinner next weekend. You'll probably go. But you realized something: when she's nice to you, you get anxious. When she's critical, you get anxious. So either way, you're anxious. That's a real insight. And you're right—the problem isn't actually about her being nice or mean. It's that you're always waiting for something bad to happen with her no matter what she does. That's the pattern. She's been critical before, and that hurt. So now you're bracing for it to happen again. But here's the thing: she's been nice this week. She listened, she cared, she gave advice that landed. And you're anxious about that, too.
